Use Twitter to find developer friends near you

22 May 2020

Being a developer can be tough, especially doing it all alone. That‚Äôs why I always recommend surrounding yourself with like-minded ‚ÄòDeveloper Friends‚Äô that support and motivate you.

Learn from each other, challenge each other, and work together to achieve the goals you set out. You‚Äôll not only learn about team dynamics but communication and collaboration. These are all important skills you‚Äôll need when working in a team as a developer.

So if you‚Äôre looking to connect with like-minded individuals in your area then this trick is for you.

I‚Äôm intrigued, go on.

Twitter has a really cool feature that not many people know about. You can search for tweets using geolocation data.

A lot of tweets are automatically tagged with geolocation data such a latitude, longitude, and radius (skip ahead if you want to disable this). Using Twitter‚Äôs own search or API we can query for tweets using these fields:

// The breakdown
geocode:latitude,longitude,radius
// Actual data
geocode:-36.8484597,174.7633315,10km
// Actual data with search terms included
geocode:40.7127753,-74.0059728,5mi "Coding" OR "Programming"

Let‚Äôs give it a try

Here we are searching for anyone tweeting related developer terms within a 5-mile radius of Facebook‚Äôs Headquarters in California.

Now make it even easier

You‚Äôre not going to want to keep Googling the coordinates and building your custom search strings each and every time. So I built a quick tool that does it all for you.

Developer Friends will accept any address, location you can throw at it and it will automatically generate the coordinates and build your custom search query for you. Include the predefined search terms with the tickboxes or even add your own in the text box.


After hitting search you‚Äôll be taken to Twitter with your own custom search query and everyone listed should be within the location and radius you specified. Now go make some developer friends. üëç

‚Ä¶

I don‚Äôt want to appear in these searches

No worries, you can disable geotagging on your tweets within Twitter‚Äôs settings. You can read more about it here

I hope you‚Äôll be able to find, follow, and make plenty of developer friends. If you know any other cool tricks, let me know on Twitter @sudo_overflow
